skill.name: torchdrug
skill.description: Graph-based drug discovery toolkit. Molecular property prediction (ADMET), protein modeling, knowledge graph reasoning, molecular generation, retrosynthesis, GNNs (GIN, GAT, SchNet), 40+ datasets, for PyTorch-based ML on molecules, proteins, and biomedical graphs.
skill.summary: Graph-based drug discovery toolkit. Molecular property prediction (ADMET), protein modeling, knowled...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown reference files. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access beyond reading its own documentation files.

content.user_title: Apply graph neural networks for drug discovery research
content.value_statement: Predict molecular properties, generate new compounds, and analyze proteins using TorchDrug ML library. Train graph neural networks on molecules, proteins, and biomedical knowledge graphs for drug discovery and computational chemistry tasks.
actual_capabilities: Predict molecular properties like solubility, toxicity, and binding affinity using GNN models (GIN, GAT, SchNet)
Generate novel drug-like molecules with autoregressive models and reinforcement learning optimization
Model protein sequences and structures using ESM, GearNet, and other protein-specific architectures
Perform knowledge graph reasoning for drug repurposing and disease mechanism discovery
Plan retrosynthesis routes using reaction center identification and synthon completion models
Train on 40+ curated datasets including BBBP, HIV, QM9, Hetionet, and USPTO-50k
limitations: Requires PyTorch and TorchDrug installation (uv pip install torchdrug)
GPU recommended for training on large datasets
Does not include pre-trained model weights (must download separately)
Domain expertise needed to interpret results for research applications

use_cases.title: ADMET property prediction
use_cases.description: Train models to predict absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion, and toxicity of drug candidates from molecular structure.

use_cases.title: De novo molecule generation
use_cases.description: Generate novel drug-like compounds optimized for target binding, drug-likeness, and synthesizability using graph-based generative models.

use_cases.title: Protein function prediction
use_cases.description: Predict enzyme function, subcellular localization, and protein-protein interactions from sequence or structure using ESM and GearNet models.

prompt_templates.title: Basic property prediction
prompt_templates.prompt: Use TorchDrug to predict molecular properties. Load the BBBP dataset, define a GIN model, and train a PropertyPrediction task with BCE loss. Use scaffold splitting and evaluate with AUROC.

prompt_templates.title: Protein function analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Use TorchDrug to predict protein function. Load the EnzymeCommission dataset, use a pre-trained ESM model, and train a PropertyPrediction task for multi-class EC number classification.

prompt_templates.title: Molecular generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use TorchDrug to generate novel molecules. Train a GraphAutoregressiveFlow on ZINC250k, then generate molecules with constraints on logP, molecular weight, and synthetic accessibility score.

prompt_templates.title: Drug repurposing
prompt_templates.prompt: Use TorchDrug for drug repurposing. Load the Hetionet knowledge graph, train a RotatE model for KnowledgeGraphCompletion, and predict novel Compound-treats-Disease relationships.

output_examples.input: Predict blood-brain barrier penetration for a molecule with SMILES 'CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)O' (aspirin)
output: TorchDrug converts SMILES to molecular graph representation with atoms and bonds
GIN model processes the graph through message passing layers
PropertyPrediction task outputs probability of BBB penetration (0-1)
Expected output: AUROC metric on test set after training, prediction scores for new molecules

best_practices: Use scaffold splitting for realistic drug discovery evaluation instead of random splits
Start with pre-trained models (ESM for proteins, InfoGraph for molecules) when data is limited
Monitor AUROC and AUPRC together for imbalanced molecular property datasets
Apply data augmentation like virtual nodes and edges for small molecular datasets
anti_patterns: Using random splits on molecular datasets causes data leakage between train and test
Training from scratch on small datasets leads to overfitting
Ignoring edge features (bond types, stereochemistry) reduces prediction accuracy
Using TransE on N-to-N relations in knowledge graphs gives poor results

faq.question: What datasets are available for molecular property prediction?
faq.answer: BBBP (blood-brain barrier), HIV (inhibition), Tox21 (toxicity), ESOL (solubility), QM9 (quantum properties), and 20+ more curated datasets with automatic downloading.

faq.question: Which GNN model should I choose for molecular tasks?
faq.answer: GIN is recommended as the first choice for most molecular property prediction tasks due to its theoretical expressiveness. Use SchNet when 3D coordinates are available.

faq.question: How do I integrate TorchDrug with AlphaFold structures?
faq.answer: Load AlphaFold PDB files using data.Protein.from_pdb(), then construct residue graphs with spatial edges using protein.residue_graph() with edge_types=['sequential', 'radius'].

faq.question: Is my data safe when using TorchDrug?
faq.answer: Yes. TorchDrug runs locally and only accesses datasets you explicitly load. No data is sent to external servers. All computation happens on your machine.

faq.question: Why is my model not learning on small protein datasets?
faq.answer: Use pre-trained ESM embeddings and fine-tune with small learning rate (1e-5). Consider freezing early layers or using frozen embeddings for datasets under 1,000 samples.

faq.question: How does TorchDrug compare to RDKit?
faq.answer: RDKit provides cheminformatics utilities (SMILES parsing, chemical rules). TorchDrug focuses on machine learning - training neural networks to predict properties and generate molecules using graph representations.
